title: Site
description_array: The 'site.json' configuration file is the global TTP configuration file for your site, and the first loaded by each command. It defines global TTP behavior.

It is searched for among (hardcoded) 'etc/ttp/site.json', 'etc/toops/site.json', 'etc/site.json', 'etc/ttp/toops.json', 'etc/toops/toops.json', 'etc/toops.json', 'etc/ttp/ttp.json', 'etc/toops/ttp.json' or 'etc/ttp.json' in each path of TTP_ROOTS environment variable.
The first found wins.
Windows notes:
- Take care of doubling your backslashes
Dynamic values:
May make use - in values only - of parameters between square brackets as [eval:...]
'eval' may be prefixed with an underscore in order to delay the eval (e.g. if it refers to another dynamic variable which needs to be resolved first).
Site variables:
The site integrator may use this same configuration file (and is encouraged to) to set his own site-level variables.
These variables are free to the site integrator and NOT considered by TheToolsProject, though they can be used when evaluating dynamic values.
Variables values can be accessed though TTP::var([ 'site', 'my', 'other', 'key' ]) the same way than TTP configuration variables.
See below 'site' object.
Unless otherwise specified, below values are overridable on a per-bode basis.
Starting with v4.16, 'command' and 'commands' properties both accept either a single string command or an array of commands,
where each individual command can be either a single string or an object with a 'byOS' property.
We can so have:
- "command": "a simple command"
- "commands": "another simple command"
- "commands": [
"yet another command -with -an -argument"
"byOS": {
"Linux": "scp -rp <SOURCE> <TARGET>"
"MSWin32": "robocopy <SOURCE> <TARGET> /MIR"
- "commands": {
"byOS": {
"linux": "scp -rp <SOURCE> <TARGET>"
"MSWin32": "robocopy <SOURCE> <TARGET> /MIR"
Commands all accept a <NODE> macro which is evaluated as TTP::nodeName().
When several commands are specified, they are executed, inconditionnally, in sequence.

description_array: Configure here each medium which can be used to send alerts via 'ttp.pl alert'. All properties can be overriden on a per-node basis.
An alert has following properties:
- emitter: defaulting to the running node name
- level: defaulting to 'INFO'
- title: a single descriptive line
- message: a more complete alert content
- stamp: automatically added by the 'ttp.pl alert' command as an ISO 8601 date and time.
Media have common properties:
- enabled: whether this medium is enabled; will be fully ignored when disabled; defaulting to true (enabled).
- default: whether this medium is a default for 'ttp.pl alert' command; defaulting to false.
- command: either a single string, or an object 'command.byOS.<osname>; defaulting dependant of the exact used medium.
Provided commands have access to following macros:
- <EMITTER> the emitter node,
- <LEVEL> the alert level (see ttp.alert --list-levels to get the list of available levels),
- <TITLE> the title of the alert,
- <MESSAGE>the message of the alert,
- <STAMP> the timestamp as a string 'yyyy-mm-dd hh:mi:ss.cccccc +02:00',
- <OPTIONS> additional options provided to the alert, most probably targeting the underlying command,
- <JSON> a JSON stringified version of the alert data,
- <ATTACHED> an optional attached piece.
When specifying a command, either as a simple string or as a 'byOS' object, you should take care that the specified command will not
inherit of '--dummy' or '--verbose' options of the parent command. Be cautious about what you exactly want.

description_array: The configuration for remote executions.
The remote execution is needed and operated when we want access a service running on another node IN THE SAME ENVIRONMENT that the source node.
The executed command is actually built from three parts:
- depending of the source node: whether to '/bin/ssh' or 'C:\Windows\Systemt32\ssh.exe' and with which parameters,
- depending of the target node: whether to '. ~/.ttp_remote' or 'C:\TheToolsProject\tools\libexec\cmd\bootstrap.cmd',
- and last with the original command, verb and arguments.
The commands have access to following macros:
- <ORIGINAL_COMMAND> the original command as in 'command.pl verb -arguments',
- <SOURCE_COMMAND> the part of the command which depends of the source node,
- <TARGET_COMMAND> the part of the command which depends of the target node,
- <TARGET_NAME> the target node name.
Note that we expect a single command (not an array). If an array is found, then we only deal with the first command.

description_array: The configuration of the telemetry.
Starting with its v3.0 version, TheToolsProject has chosen Prometheus ecosystem to host its telemetry, while keeping the capability
to have a messaging-based (MQTT) telemetry. Prometheus let us sent our telemetry either via the PushGateway or via the TextFileCollector.
You can note that TTP does not provide any Prometheus exporter.
The three (MQTT, HTTP and TextFile) medias are both configurable here.
Prometheus defines its metrics as an object with following properties:
- a name,
- a numeric value,
- an optional help line,
- an optional list of labels defined as "name"="value".
Please note that, while the list of labels is unordered from Prometheus point of view, and so unordered in HTTP PushGateway and text TextFile collector,
it is ordered from MQTT point of view because they can be parts of the built topic.
The labels may vary from verb to verb, but always start with 'host=<NODE>'.
The following macros are available to the 'telemetry.pl' verbs:
- <NAME>: the metric name, always 'ttp_'-prefixed,
- <VALUE>: the metric value, always a scalar, must be a numerical value when publishing on HTTP or TextFile,
- <HELP>: the metric help line,
- <LABELS>: the provided (ordered) labels as a comma-separated string,
- <LABEL_NAMES>: the provided (ordered) label names as a comma-separated string,
- <LABEL_VALUES>: the provided (ordered) label values as a comma-separated string.
The 'telemetry.pl ping' verb let us ping any device, providing an errors count and a latency.
The verb honors all telemetry macros, plus following ones:
- <DEVICE>: the device name.
- <SUFFIX>: the configured suffix for the metric.
When alerting is enabled, the used media are chosen based on the general site 'alerts' configuration.
When publishing is enabled, the used media are chosen based on the general site 'telemetry' configuration.

description_array: The configuration of how and when publish workloads summaries.
Workloads are defined at the service level, and are just a list of commands executed at various times.
They provide their results as a list of the executed commands, with a start and end date and time, and a return code.
The respective workload.cmd/workload.sh default to try to publish a workload summary per workload (but see below for other options).
Publishing a 'per period' workloads summary means than we publish a summary for all workloads executed (actually started) during a given period.
In such a situation, two commands must be specified:
- first is how to get the (previously recorded) list of workload summaries,
- second is how to publish them.
The command(s) to get the workloads summaries to be dealt with.
It is expected to produce a JSON file which contains an array of the workloads results.
The configured command(s) have access to following macros:
- <JSONFNAME> the path to a temporary file which will eventually contain the JSON data produced by the command(s),
- <SINCE> the date and time of the start of the considered period, as a 'YYYY-MM-DD HH:MI:SS.CC' string,
- <UNTIL> the date and time of the end of the considered period, as a 'YYYY-MM-DD HH:MI:SS.CC' string.

Publishing a 'per command' workload summary means than we publish the result for each executed command inside of a workload as soon as this later is ended.

- <ENDED> the command end date and time as 'YYYY-MM-DD HH:MI:SS.CC',
- <RC> the command return code.
